intro: Lupinus xanthophyllus, commonly known as the yellow-flowered lupine, is a species native to the western United States. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Lupinus xanthophyllus is also valued for its nitrogen-fixing ability, which benefits soil fertility in agricultural settings.
